questions.text: A 1-year-old boy, previously healthy until five months ago, presents with a three-hour history of severe swelling and tenderness of hands and feet. The family history is significant for an older brother who had transfusion-dependent anaemia and died of pneumococcal sepsis at the age of 6. Which haemoglobin molecule composition protected him from developing symptoms until recently?

Which of the following points best describes the pathogenesis of sickle cell disease (SCD)? Select all that apply. Nonsense point mutation in 6th position of β-globin chain Mutation promotes the polymerization of oxygenated hemoglobin Glutamic acid is changed to valine at the 6th position of β-globin chain Presence of HbF and HbS is protective against SCD. Patients heterozygous for HbS have more severe diseases than homozygous HbS. Individuals with coexistent α-thalassemia have less severe disease.
Which of the following conditions does not lead to sickling of RBCs in patients with sickle cell disease?

A 28-year-old man who has received blood transfusions on some occasions and has experienced severe pain in his hands and legs came to follow up. He is currently fine with no complaints and has been receiving treatment that has increased his HbF levels for the past 5 years. Which of the following would be seen in the peripheral smear of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Encapsulated bacteria
  • Pneumococcus
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Bordetella holmesii

Bloodborne parasites
  • Babesia spp
  • Plasmodium spp

questions.text: Match the complications of sickle cell disease (SCD) with their corresponding crises: Complications Crises 1. Acute chest syndrome A. Vaso-occlusive crises 2. Parvovirus B19 infection B. Aplastic crises 3. Splenic enlargement C. Sequestration crisis 4. Splenic fibrosis

A 12-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, pallor, and jaundice. Peripheral smear showed sickling of RBCs. What is the most likely electrophoretic pattern seen in this patient?

Which of the following statements regarding the different types of thalassemia is correct? Thalassemia major - mutations in both alleles of the HBB gene - impaired production of beta-globin chains. Beta-thalassemia trait - mutations in one allele of the HBB gene - reduced beta-globin chain synthesis. Alpha-thalassemia trait - deletions in one or more alpha-globin genes - decreased production of alpha-globin chains. Thalassemia intermedia - mutations affecting both alpha and beta-globin genes - severe anemia requiring regular blood transfusions

A 25-year-old male presents with fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic hypochromic anemia with increased levels of serum iron and ferritin. Further genetic analysis reveals a mutation in the HBB gene. Upon histopathological examination of the bone marrow, there is evidence of erythroid hyperplasia with ineffective erythropoiesis. Which mutation in the HBB gene is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: Substitution of cytosine for guanine at position 8 in the promoter region of the HBB gene.

options.label: B
options.text: Substitution of one nucleotide at position +8 in the coding region of the HBB gene.

options.label: C
options.text: Splicing mutation resulting in the removal of intervening sequence-IVS1-5 G-> C in the HBB gene.

options.label: D
options.text: Insertion of a nucleotide at position 54 in the coding region of the HBB gene

questions.correct_answer: C. Splicing mutation resulting in the removal of intervening sequence-IVS1-5 G-> C in the HBB gene.
questions.explanation:
FEATURE

THALASSEMIA MAJOR

THALASSEMIA INTERMEDIA

THALASSEMIA MINOR

Beta chain production

No beta chain

production.

present.

normal.

Splenomegaly

Hb (gm/dl)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with beta-thalassemia major presents to the cardiology clinic with complaints of increasing shortness of breath on exertion and swelling in her ankles. She has been undergoing regular blood transfusions since childhood. She dies after a few days of hospitalization. What is the most common condition leading to her death?

A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic for routine prenatal care. She has no significant past medical history. Her initial lab work reveals a microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Which of the following statements is most accurate in differentiating between iron deficiency anemia (IDA) and beta-thalassemia minor in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: RDW is typically elevated in IDA compared to beta-thalassemia minor

options.label: B
options.text: RDW is typically lower in IDA compared to beta-thalassemia minor

options.label: C
options.text: Mentzer index is >13 in beta-thalassemia minor

options.label: D
options.text: RDW is typically normal in both IDA and beta-thalassemia minor

questions.correct_answer: A. RDW is typically elevated in IDA compared to beta-thalassemia minor
questions.explanation:
Feature

Iron Deficiency Anemia

Beta Thalassemia Minor

Type

Microcytic hypochromic anemia

Microcytic hypochromic anemia

RBC

Less

More

MCV

Normal to low

Low

RDW(size variance)

More

Normal

Mentzer index: MCV/RBC

>13

<13

Reticulocyte count

Low

Normal to slightly increased

HbA2 - confirmatory test

<3.5%

>3.5%

questions.text: A hematologist is reviewing the peripheral blood smears of three patients diagnosed with different types of thalassemia. Patient A has severe anemia, target cells, and nucleated red blood cells (NRBCs). Patient B has mild anemia with microcytosis and hypochromia but no NRBCs. Patient C has mild anemia with microcytosis and hypochromia but also shows a small number of NRBCs and some hemoglobin H inclusions. Based on the peripheral smear findings, which of the following correctly matches the patients with their thalassemia types?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient A: β-thalassemia major, Patient B: β-thalassemia minor, Patient C: α-thalassemia

options.label: B
options.text: Patient A: β-thalassemia minor, Patient B: α-thalassemia, Patient C: β-thalassemia major

options.label: C
options.text: Patient A: α-thalassemia, Patient B: β-thalassemia minor, Patient C: β-thalassemia major

options.label: D
options.text: Patient A: β-thalassemia major, Patient B: α-thalassemia, Patient C: β-thalassemia minor

questions.correct_answer: A. Patient A: β-thalassemia major, Patient B: β-thalassemia minor, Patient C: α-thalassemia

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most consistent with β thalassemia major when compared to β thalassemia minor?

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in HbA, slight increase in HbA2, and normal HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 2%

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in HbA, increase in HbA2, and marked increase in HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 90%

options.label: C
options.text: Absent HbA, slight increase in HbA2, and moderate increase in HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 4%, HbF: 20%

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease in HbA, normal HbA2, and normal HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 2%, HbF: 2%

questions.correct_answer: B. Decrease in HbA, increase in HbA2, and marked increase in HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 90%

questions.text: A pregnant woman is a silent carrier for α-thalassemia (α-/αα) and is concerned about the risk of her child inheriting α-thalassemia. Her partner has the α-thalassemia trait (αα/--). What is the probability that their child will have Hemoglobin H (HbH) disease?
questions.explanation:
Type of Alpha Thalassemia

Affected Alpha Genes

Clinical Features

Genotype

Silent Carrier

1 out of 4 genes

Typically asymptomatic, mild microcytosis

-α/αα or αα/-α

Mild anemia, microcytosis, hypochromia

-α/-α (trans) or --/αα (cis)

3 out of 4 genes

Moderate to severe anemia, hemolysis, splenomegaly, bone changes

Severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, usually fatal in utero or shortly after birth

Type of Alpha Thalassemia

Affected Alpha Genes

Clinical Features

Genotype

Hemoglobin Analysis

Silent Carrier

1 out of 4 genes

Typically asymptomatic, mild microcytosis

-α/αα or αα/-α

Normal or slightly reduced MCV and MCH

2 out of 4 genes

Mild anemia, microcytosis, hypochromia

-α/-α (trans) or --/αα (cis)

Reduced MCV, MCH, normal Hb electrophoresis

Hemoglobin H Disease

3 out of 4 genes

Moderate to severe anemia, hemolysis, splenomegaly, bone changes

--/-α

4 out of 4 genes

Severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, usually fatal in utero or shortly after birth

--/--

Presence of Hb Bart's (γ4)

questions.text: The medical team, aware of the prevalence of genetic disorders in the village decides to implement a screening process using NESTROFT for beta thalassemia. They plan to test the result by observing the solution turning clear by checking the visibility of a black line behind the test and control tubes. Which of the following on Nestrof test would be indicative of a positive result?

options.label: A
options.text: Black line visible in both tubes

options.label: B
options.text: Black line visible in only control tubes

options.label: C
options.text: Black line visible in only test tubes

options.label: D
options.text: No black line visible in any of the tubes

questions.correct_answer: C. Black line visible in only test tubes

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their respective antibodies and target antigens on red blood cells (RBCs): 1. Cold Agglutinin Disease 2. Cold Hemolytic Disease Antibody Target Antigen on RBCs A IgM I antigen B IgG P antigen C IgG I antigen D IgM P antigen Select the correct matching pairs:
questions.explanation:
Feature

Cold Agglutinin Disease (CAD)

Cold Hemolytic Disease (CHD) / Paroxysmal Cold Haemoglobinuria(PCH)

Antibody Type

IgM antibodies against the I antigen on RBCs.

IgG antibodies against the P antigen on RBCs.

Temperature Sensitivity

Bind avidly at low temperatures (0°C to 4°C), but not at 37°C

Bind in cool peripheral regions, but complement-mediated lysis occurs at warm core

Causes

Associated with certain infections (Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, influenza virus, HIV), B-cell neoplasms, or idiopathic

Often seen in children following viral infections

Hemolysis

Intravascular hemolysis is usually not seen; extravascular hemolysis due to phagocytosis after release of IgM

Complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria

Clinical Symptoms

Pallor, cyanosis, Raynaud phenomenon in cold-exposed body parts

Hemoglobinuria, intravascular hemolysis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding warm antibody-mediated autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA)?

options.label: A
options.text: It is commonly mediated by IgG antibodies active at 37°C.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be associated with the intake of drugs like alpha-methyldopa and quinine.

options.label: C
options.text: It typically involves the destruction of red blood cells primarily in the liver.

options.label: D
options.text: A positive direct Coombs test is often used to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.correct_answer: C. It typically involves the destruction of red blood cells primarily in the liver.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Antibody Type

IgG

Optimal Temperature for Activity

37°C (body temperature)

Common Symptoms

Fatigue, pallor, jaundice, shortness of breath, dark urine, splenomegaly

Mechanism of Hemolysis

IgG antibodies bind to RBCs, leading to phagocytosis primarily in the spleen

Diagnosis

Positive direct Coombs test (direct antiglobulin test)

Hemolysis Location

Primarily in the spleen

Associated Conditions

Autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus), lymphoproliferative disorders, infections

Drug-Induced Causes

Alpha-methyldopa, quinine, penicillin, and cephalosporins

Laboratory Findings

Anemia, elevated reticulocyte count, increased LDH, Decreased haptoglobin, spherocytes on blood smear
